christian.overview: The lion holds profound significance in Christian symbolism, representing both Christ as the "Lion of Judah" and, paradoxically, Satan as a "roaring lion seeking whom he may devour." This dual symbolism reflects Scripture's complex use of leonine imagery.

biblicalParallels.description: Christ is called the "Lion of the tribe of Judah, the Root of David," who has conquered and can open the sealed scroll.
Jacob's blessing of Judah as a "lion's cub" establishes the messianic lion symbolism fulfilled in Christ.
The devil is likened to a "roaring lion, seeking someone to devour," showing the lion's negative symbolic potential.
Daniel in the lions' den prefigures Christ's descent into death and resurrection, with the lions' mouths shut by divine power.
The lion face of the living creatures represents regal power and majesty in the divine presence.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers developed extensive leonine Christology and also explored the lion's role in representing courage, nobility, and watchfulness.

sources.author: Origen
sources.interpretation: Distinguished Christ as the true Lion who conquers through sacrifice (the Lamb who is also Lion) from Satan's false leonine ferocity.

sources.author: Augustine of Hippo
sources.interpretation: Christ's resurrection is like a lion: ancient legend held that lion cubs are born dead and awakened by their father's roar on the third day - a natural type of resurrection.

sources.author: Ambrose of Milan
sources.interpretation: The lion sleeping with eyes open represents Christ's body in the tomb while his divinity remained vigilant.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: Medieval bestiaries detailed three "natures" of the lion, all applied to Christ: (1) erasing tracks with tail (hiding divine nature), (2) sleeping with eyes open (death with divine vigilance), (3) breathing life into stillborn cubs (resurrection).
medievalSymbolism.evangelistSymbol: The lion represents the Gospel of Mark (or in some schemes, John), symbolizing Christ's royal dignity and power over death.
medievalSymbolism.artisticRepresentation: Lions guard cathedral entrances (especially in Romanesque architecture), representing Christ's protection and the courage required to enter sacred space.
medievalSymbolism.heraldry: The lion became the preeminent symbol of Christian kingship, representing courage, justice, and Christ-like sovereignty.

christian.typologicalReading: Daniel among the lions prefigures the Harrowing of Hell: as Daniel was preserved in the lions' den and emerged on the third day at royal command, so Christ descended among the powers of death and rose victorious.
christian.dualSymbolism: The lion's dual use (Christ and Satan) teaches that symbols derive meaning from context: the same power that protects the faithful terrorizes God's enemies; the same ferocity that characterizes evil can be transformed into divine majesty.
christian.liturgicalPresence: Lion imagery appears in Christian liturgy through the reading of Revelation 5:5 (Lion of Judah) and in prayers invoking protection from spiritual predators (1 Peter 5:8-9).
